newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call money ends flat, gilt prices steady.
newsitem.headline: Indian call money ends flat, gilt prices steady.

text.p: Indian call money was quoted in the 0.5-0.75 percent range at close of trade on Wednesday, little changed from the day's opening quotes, dealers said.
They said call rates remained easy on good liquidity and poor demand for funds.
"At the moment, everyone seems to have funds in plenty," said a dealer at a foreign bank. "There are few borrowers."
Dealers said they expected call money rates to remain easy for the rest of the week but they could harden slightly next week as companies made advance tax payments.
The last date for such payments is December 15 and some dealers said the outflow of funds on this account could cause some tightening. But other dealers differed.
"Corporate earnings are down in the first half of the year," said a dealer. "As such their tax liabilities may not be high."
Dealers said prices of governemnt securities were steady in moderate trade.
"There were a number of sellers today but not many buyers," said a dealer. "There was major movement in prices."

The 13.85 percent 2001 government of India stock traded on Wednesday at a yield of 13.44 percent against its last trade of 13.46 percent, dealers said. The 13.55 percent 2001 stock was traded at 13.48 percent against 13.51, they said.
